review_title: Culture with new CEO is supposedly more transparent and equitable but it's not
pros: Depending on what office you work for, there is flexibility (schedule). If you are hired by the Asian or Latin American offices, there is little to no flexibility.
cons: We keep hearing that offices are autonomous but the headquarters office has always the last word. There is little room to make our own decisions because the headquarters office is always watching and providing feedback on anything that's done outside its realm. The current CEO is supposedly more equitable but she has only raised her friends' salaries. She is friends with other staff that were promoted after she was promoted to CEO. She is a recognized public figure in the forced displacement field who shows herself as someone who believes in fairness but she doesn't walk the talk. The CEO is too young to lead an international nonprofit and lacks the management and experience and vision the former CEO had.

review_title: Values-based organization that cares about its people
pros: Values-based, authentic, hardworking, thoughtful place to work. Ask for what you need and assuming its mission-aligned and financially feasible it'll probably be taken up.
cons: International work means strange hours. Hard to avoid. It's important to have strong personal boundaries.

review_title: Independently working with tons of experiences, but less work life balance
pros:
- able to independently, creatively and freely contribute and develop the community based projects and how to improve the legal service in the minor level.
- have a great chance to learn from other volunteers and acquire many skills set; like legal counseling skills and project management skills
cons:
- more experience acquired, less time to take care own well-being
- limited Human Resources with unrealistic goals to be succeed in a year project
- top-down management/ not take the context and local staffs opinion into account when developing the projects.

review_title: Dream job in the making
pros:
I've worked with Asylum Access Headquarters (HQ) for four years now and in that time I've witnessed an impressive growth spurt as the organization's expanded to several new countries. Through the process I've never seen a team work so hard to offer its employees the highest quality support and benefits possible.

I'll admit, in the beginning the pay was low and benefits were few. But the organization's model and strategic approach is solid. The people I have had the pleasure to work with are honest, down-to-earth, dedicated, communicative and extremely professional.

After sticking with Asylum Access HQ for four years, it's really paying off. My job description and salary have been improved significantly based on my interests and needs. I can work remotely and still feel like I'm part of a team. Finally, I feel like there is still a lot of room to grow within the organization in the years to come, and I definitely can't complain about the amount of paid time off we get.
cons:
- It can be hard to feel connected with staff and volunteers in other countries and their achievements. 
- In my line of work and likely because I work remotely, there is a lot of computer time, which is exhausting.
- Late night meetings with our team in other timezones sometimes make it difficult to maintain a work/life balance. That said, there is flexibility around work schedules.

review_title: Amazing organization
pros: Noble mission, amazing cross-cultural experience
cons: When I was there there were some management issues but I understand it’s better now

review_title: Changing lives and policies globally; working to treat staff right
pros:
Asylum Access's mission is to make refugee rights a reality. We influence refugees' lives 1 by 1 and also change policies and make laws nationally and globally.

Generally, I love working at Asylum Access because the mission moves me and our impact is tangible. We are a team that works hard and are dedicated to making change happen. At Asylum Access a sense of humor is also deeply appreciated. While I have felt some of the growing pains of transitioning from a start-up organization to a larger global institution, the organization continues to take important steps to ensure staff well being. 

The refugee rights field is small and insular and our volunteer and staff alums all over the world -it is exciting to see our alums in so many important places and continue to make a difference in human rights.
cons: The organization is growing FAST and lots of work falls on the shoulders of a few staff and very key volunteers. I hear we will see better salaries and redistribution of roles to continue to address the symptoms of such growth and frankly, the demands of an ever growing, needy refugee population globally. It helps to have lots of PTO and a flexible work-from-home policy and knowing that the org cares about its people. Changes are being made in response to staff requests.

review_title: Communications and Development Intern
pros: This internship offered me the chance to gain experience and skills in a wide variety of different tasks in communications and development.  My managers were friendly and supportive, always providing clear guidance on what was needed and were available when I gad questions. They provided constructive and encouraging feedback after I completed work. The work environment is professional but relaxed and I had tge chance to meet and work with people from diverse countries.  Its a great place to meet friends. Also with the alumni network you can get updates about upcoming job vacancies in the field. Overall I think it is an internship where you can get hands on experience in a growing international organization doing very worthwhile work.
cons: Quite a lot of independent working is required so using your initiative is necessary. As a growing organization many staff are very busy, causing strain and difficulties in retention. Some systems are not fully consolidated so there are inefficiencies but as an intern you may be asked to so work on this which gives an interesting insight into the fundamentals of the organization.

review_title: I learned so much and got to contribute to Asylum Access's fantastic work and mission
pros: Asylum Access's work impacts thousands of refugees around the world, and it's great to be a part of that. Volunteers get to do client-oriented work on the ground, implementing Asylum Access's mission. Asylum Access staff is truly passionate about helping refugee communities overcome obstacles preventing them from empowerment and rebuilding their lives.
cons: Headquarters is out of touch with volunteers on the ground. Local management is good at dealing with local authorities and affecting policy, but is horrifying ineffective at fostering the kind of warm, supportive, team-like atmosphere that foreign volunteers need to thrive. Despite what volunteers actually accomplish and the practical skills they acquire, they often leave feeling frustrated, under-appreicated, emotionally drained, exhausted. I was full-time for almost two years and heard the same complaints from volunteers over and over, and headquarters didn't seem to take them seriously. I also felt overworked and underappreciated (with some notable exceptions- there are some true gems around the organization!)

review_title: Powerful Mission with Thoughtful, Intelligent Staff and Volunteers
pros:
I've worked at Asylum Access full time for several years. I came to the organization because of the mission and commitment to changing the status quo for refugees. In all honesty, I have stayed because of the interesting, thoughtful, motivating staff and volunteers I have met around the world. I count myself incredibly blessed to come to work and speak with passionate leaders in Ecuador, Mexico, Thailand, Tanzania, Malaysia. The VLAs I have met are so committed to using their careers to make change. 
Asylum Access also takes investment in local leadership seriously. All of our directors are nationals of their country of operation, as are senior leadership in each country. In Senior leadership, many are women, some are parents or heads of households, everyone I have met is a powerhouse.
cons: It can be difficult to be part of an organization that is growing. Sometimes there is too much work, and too few systems to support all aspects of employee and volunteer wellbeing. Those on the "front lines" can experience burn out (which is pretty normal when working in this field). Cultural differences can arise among or within offices because we have such diverse staff and volunteers. But many of these things have the attention of HQ leadership and have timelines for being addressed.

review_title: Amazing work, but management approach must be improved
pros:
Dedicated refugee rights NGOs with solid principles, dedicated to the cause 
You get excellent hands on experience
cons:
US Management seem to be focusing on global growth rather than ensuring their staff are supported and their current overseas offices are operating as well as they could be 

Exploitative business model - especially for local staff (who were all amazing) they are paid badly and work in high stress environments with little support and training as everything is done on a shoe-string budget. They wouldn't expect US staff to do such traumatic work on equivalent salaries with little support but is deemed acceptable in their country offices. 

Loss of institutional knowledge - crazy high staff turnover so continuity of work isn't great, cases are lost, clients have to deal with constantly changing advocates 

Combination of these factors means there isn't as much downward accountability to the populations they are serving as there should be.

review_title: Volunteer Legal Advocate
job_title: Owner, Aretz & Chisholm Immigration in Quito
pros: There is absolutely no better way to understand the workings of international refugee law without seeing it first hand, and no better way to learn to appreciate the strength and resolve of a refugee without hearing their story in person, in their native language. I was so proud of my supervisors, my work, and my colleagues. I was stretched and challenged in ways that are very uncommon for recent law school graduates; working for Asylum Access was the perfect way to launch my legal career.
cons: It was financially difficult to work abroad without compensation, but well worth it. By it's very nature, the VLA position is one of in depth training and once-in-a-lifetime experiences. It taught me a great many lessons and skills that helped me find the right position after returning from my time in Quito. I also think it is wise to require a 6 month commitment, but not to encourage a stay much longer than that (as a VLA).

review_title: A Truly Inspiring crew
pros: The single best and brightest group I've ever worked with. The people are passionate, smart, driven, dedicated and mutually supportive. The work could not be more meaningful and impactful and everyone here takes it very seriously.  I am proud to be working among them. Focus is ever-refining and improving systems and processes (and compensation packages). The hours are flexible and the settling is in a vibrant area of Oakland.
cons: Hours can be long and unsteady (as overseas offices have significant time differences, so those meetings can be at crazy hours). Process of constant improvement means constant change, which can be difficult for some folks to manage. Compensation packages are a little below industry standard (in this region with a very expensive cost of living), but efforts are underway to bring them up to standard. The work can be very hard but equally rewarding.

review_title: Awful Management
pros: Working directly with refugees, learning about local law and procedures.
cons:
I volunteered for 6 months in one of the Latin America offices. Lack of communication between regional offices and staff.  AA has an open door policy of communication - the reality is the complete opposite. Awful atmosphere, management clueless. As a volunteer I felt underappreciated and emotionally drained - mainly due to the aforementioned issues. Lack of training. High turnover led to disorganization and lack of work fluidity. Lack of experts working in the office. US main office seems to be clueless of what's happening in other offices.
Sounded like an amazing experience on the website - severely disappointed.

review_title: Great place to start your international human rights career
pros: Unlike some of the other reviews, I found the Asylum Access HQ leadership to be incredibly driven, passionate, and supportive.  Asylum Access is a great organization for someone beginning their career and look to gain practical experience.
cons: The downsides of working with Asylum Access are, unfortunately, fairly common among young, ambitious, underfunded NGOs. They rely heavily upon volunteers to accomplish much of their amazing work, and sometimes the leadership are simply not in a place to provide the staff support or other comforts that larger not-for-profits may be able to provide. But what one lacks in comfort or support, one gains in the ability to jump right in, to get immediate practical experience, and to use one's own passions and ambitions to direct the future growth of the organization.

review_title: A place with promise; a mission with meaning
pros:
Asylum Access is full of value-driven, mission-centric, results-oriented people. Everyone cares deeply about the wellbeing of refugees and asylum seekers, and is willing to go the extra mile to reach the mission.

The mission itself is my favorite part of working here -- Asylum Access is a missing ingredient in refugee response. We change lives on the ground, we change policies impacting millions, and more than even that, we represent the thought that refugees deserve more than just indefinite handouts -- they desire to rebuild their lives. 

Generous PTO, flexible family policies, constantly improving salary scales.
cons: During growth phases, we must work very hard. Good thing there is generous PTO.

review_title: Good opportunity for the right people, but unlikely to be somewhere to stay long term
pros:
-Refugee work is a very small and competitive field, Asylum Access is a great place to get into that field and get some initial experience.
-Because they cannot offer competitive salaries, young, inexperienced go-getters can get a chance to prove themselves and get trained.
-The organization is incredibly devoted to their mission and orients their work around their sincere respect for refugees as individuals with rights.
-There are some truly great, hardworking and committed people working with Asylum Access in the US and abroad, who have an inspiring dedication to their work.
-For many positions, staff can be incredibly flexible in how they structure their work, and are given a great deal of trust that they are doing their job, even if they are working remotely, from another country, or at odd hours.
cons:
-The organization offers low pay, and has a tendency to bring on new hires at an increased salary before bringing existing staff salaries up to market rate.
-The organization is struggling to let go of the "start-up" mentality, and holds itself back in substantial ways as a result. There is a total failure to bring critical systems and infrastructure up to speed before increasing workload, and they are only digging themselves into deeper challenges down the road as a result.
-Work and responsibilities are unequally held among staff, and many people are doing work that they do not have strong skills or experience in. This, combined with the scale and gravity of the refugee crisis that the organization is trying to address, often leads to a stressful and frustrating work environment where it often feels like you are simply moving from one crisis to the next, and not making progress on critical work and the improvement of existing infrastructure.
-The organization is unable or unwilling to slow their growth to a responsible rate. This has led to reduced impact around their mission and a very embarrassing rate of staff turnover. 
-Because there is so much flexibility, and the staff is already scattered around the world, there is little sense of cohesion of the team, or accountability to one another. A few staff members exploit the inherent flexibility and do not seem to be actually working very much.

review_title: Great NGO, and great people
pros: I interned for a summer at the Oakland office. I had such a positive experience. I loved my supervisor and have so much respect for all of the badass women who run this organization. My fellow interns are now friends for life. I learned a lot about international refugee law through the internship--I was given flexibility in deciding which topics I wanted to work on based on what was most interesting to me. The staff went out of their way to create a feeling of community in the office--lunches together, gathering at a director's home, etc.
cons: I honestly cannot think of any!

review_title: Wonderful Work Environment-- Positive, Empowering, Enriching
pros:
During my time at Asylum Access, I not only felt that the work that I was doing had a greater, positive effect in the world, but I also felt that my time and input was valued and respected. I was a summer intern at the Oakland headquarters office, and I had the opportunity to work closely with Emily Arnold-Fernandez, Diana Essex-Lettieri, Jessica Therkelsen, and Anna Wirth, as well as many of the other full time staffers. My experience was nothing but positive-- I was inspired daily by the dedication and intelligence of my coworkers, and often empowered by my superiors to carry out research projects and other tasks that supported the mission of the organization. I never felt like I was doing busy work intended for an intern. Criticism was always constructive, and collaboration and creativity was encouraged. There was also flexibility and understanding with my schedule-- I was allowed to work from home when I needed to. 

In my opinion, no other organization I've worked for, including the UN, has a better model for enacting positive change in international human rights for refugees than Asylum Access.  Although it is headquartered in Oakland, CA, Asylum Access has satellite offices throughout Asia, Latin America, and Africa dedicated to providing on-site legal aid to refugees in first countries of refuge. Asylum Access's bottom-up, grassroots approach makes real, substantive change in the lives of its clients. Asylum Access also collaborates with local and international interest groups, governments, and NGOs to lobby for public policy change to promote greater human rights for refugees in the countries of first refuge. Asylum Access's multi-faceted approach provides an opportunity to tackle violations of refugee rights from a wider variety of angles, providing a more holistic solution than the vast majority of similar organizations. 

Overall, my time with Asylum Access was the ideal work experience for me, and I feel very lucky to have gotten to work at this dynamic organization with this wonderful group of people.
cons: I wasn't paid for my time, so I have no personal knowledge about the quality of the compensation and benefits at Asylum Access.

review_title: Poor Management
pros: Access to clients and opportunity to apply legal skills outside the classroom.
cons: The quality of the training promised is below expectations. The local management is clueless and lacks the skills necessary to create a team like environment, hence, not conducive to retention of qualified volunteers. Local management cares very little about the volunteers' experience and more about their own which creates feelings of frustration and under-appreciation. US senior management is out of touch with its volunteers and very reluctant to question their own choice of management staff as well as as their policies.

review_title: Volunteer Legal Advocate
job_title: Volunteer Legal Advocate in Kuala Lumpur
pros: You interact with some of the most vulnerable populations. You have a lot of responsibility at your job
cons: The staff is constantly changing and often no one from the management section is even at the office. It was very very disorganized and chaotic. My immediate supervisors was barely in the office and one of the most hypocritical persons I have ever met in my life.

review_title: Great Mission, Innovative Approaches, Crisis in Direction/Leadership
pros: Leading refugee rights NGO with a global team dedicated toward realizing Asylum Access's mission.
cons: Employees are underpaid and overworked.

review_title: Meaningful work, lots of responsibility
pros: The work is relevant, timely and there is lots of scope for responsibility
cons: A small budget makes some programs difficult to run effectively

review_title: Intern
pros: Good technical experience and insight into non profit
cons: no parking down town, must bus or bart

review_title: legal services
pros: great work, great people, stimulating environment
cons: low pay and low vacation allowance

review_title: Bad management. High turnover. Volunteers are unhappy.
pros: Great mission. Volunteers get firsthand access to clients and can actually make a difference in their lives.
cons: Executive Director has no management skills.
